DataElement.preferredName: Patient Colorectal Malignant Neoplasm Metastatic Eligibility Determination Ind-2
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the yes/no indicator related to eligibility of patients with a tumor composed of atypical neoplastic having to do with the colon or the rectum with clinical or pathologic observation of a tumor extension from its original site of growth to another anatomic site.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Patient Colorectal Malignant Neoplasm Metastatic Eligibility Determination
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to eligibility of patients with a tumor composed of atypical neoplastic having to do with the colon or the rectum with clinical or pathologic observation of a tumor extension from its original site of growth to another anatomic site.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A person who requires medical care.

Concepts.definition: A person who receives medical attention, care, or treatment, or who is registered with medical professional or institution with the purpose to receive medical care when necessary.

Property.preferredName: Colorectal Malignant Neoplasm Metastatic Eligibility Determination
Property.preferredDefinition: (ko-lo-REK-tul) Having to do with the colon or the rectum.:A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004:(MET-uh-STAT-ik) Having to do with metastasis, which is the spread of cancer from one part of the body to another.:Criteria to determine eligibility of patients for medical care programs and services.

Concepts.definition: Relating to the colon and rectum, or to the entire large bowel.

A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
A term referring to the clinical or pathologic observation of a tumor extension from its original site of growth to another anatomic site.
The act of determining if a subject is suitable for enrollment in a study according specific protocol criteria and procedures.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: trial-specific criteria that a patient must meet to be enrolled.

DataElementConcept.origin: NCCTG CRF:North Central Cancer Treatment Group Case Report Form

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The preferred Value Domain to indicate a question with permissible values of yes/no.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The non-affirmative response to a question.

Concepts.definition: The non-affirmative response to a question.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The affirmative response to a question.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Conceptual domain that includes value meanings to be used for Indicator Value Meanings such as Yes, No, Unknown, No Applicable

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A caDSR representation term that is used to indicate a question with permissible values of yes/no

Concepts.definition: A response or indicator that can have a value of either yes or no.

ReferenceDocuments.name: Patients must have metastatic
ReferenceDocuments.description: Patients must have metastatic colorectal cancer that has been histologically or cytologically confirmed

ReferenceDocuments.name: CRF Text 2
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does the patient have rectal cancer other than adenocarcinoma (i.e., sarcoma, lymphoma, squamous cell carcinoma, mucosal melanoma, etc.)?
